III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Staff qualifications; volunteer, contractors on central registry
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12206
Section (1) An agency shall require a staff member who has ongoing
Description contact with children or parents to be a person who has the ability,
experience, education, and training to perform the duties
assigned.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation.
Type
Allegation The Foster Care Supervisor yelled and berated the caregiver
during a telephone call related to an issue that happened
pertaining to the foster children.
Investigation Interviews:
On 5/6/2024 I reviewed the complaint allegations with the
Caregiver and interviewed the Caregiver by telephone. The
Caregiver reported the complaint is not about an inappropriate
removal of her grandchildren from her home, as the complaint
information had suggested. The complaint is about the Foster
Care Supervisor’s unprofessional behavior and tone in speaking
with her on an issue involving her grandchildren on 5/3/2024.
The Caregiver reported she has placement of her three
grandchildren, Child 1(age 16), Child 2 (age 12) and Child 3 (age
11). She reported on 5/2/2024 Child 1 told her therapist
something about a conversation that occurred with the birth
mother and the Foster Care Worker and Foster Care Supervisor
called the Caregiver about this and reported all three children
would be going for a weekend visit with Child 2’s and Child 3’s
father. It was not Child 2’s and Child 3’s scheduled week to visit
their father, and Child 1 normally did not attend the weekend
visits. The Caregiver reported during the call the Foster Care
Supervisor yelled at her and berated her. She told the Foster Care
Supervisor three times to stop yelling at her. The Caregiver said
there was no one else on her end who heard the Foster Care
Supervisor yelling at her. She did not contact the Foster Care
Supervisor’s supervisor, or another agency administrator to
complain about the Foster Care Supervisor’s behavior, or to file a
grievance of the matter. She said the incident happened late on
Friday and it was too late to call the agency then. Nor did she call
the agency, or agency administrator to complain about the matter
since then.
2

The Caregiver reported an understanding that it may be her word
against the Foster Care Supervisor’s.
On 5/6/2024 I spoke with the Chief Administrator (CA) about the
allegations by telephone. The CA reported having no reason to
believe either the Foster Care Worker or Foster Care Supervisor
would behave in an unprofessional manner with any caregiver.
She denied either staff having disciplinary actions against them.
The CA wanted it known the case this matter connects to is an
unusual one. The reason being due to its prior county’s familial
connections causing it to be transferred; and that the Caregiver is
very angry the birth mother isn’t getting the children back.
Additionally, that there was an incident involving the birthmother
and Child 1 whereby the birth mother was irate and verbally
attacked Child 1 over the children possibly being placed with Child
2’s and Child 3’s birth father. During that incident, the Caregiver
was present; and the incident caused Child 1 to have an anxiety
attack. Child 2 and Child 3 also witnessed the incident between
Child 1 and the birth mother, and they too are having anxiety to
the point of vomiting. The Foster Care Worker and Foster
Supervisor Care had a phone conversation with the Caregiver
about this incident, and a visitation plan for the children. The CA
reported no knowledge of either staff berating the Caregiver.
On 5/6/2024 I interviewed the Foster Care Supervisor about the
allegations by telephone. She confirmed the information about the
case as reported by the Chief Administrator; but denied the
allegations. She reported after Child 1’s therapist expressed
concern about an incident between Child 1 and the birth mother;
how Child 1 was very upset over the birth mother’s and
Caregiver’s actions at that incident; the agency sought to speak
with the Caregiver about the incident. The Foster Care Supervisor
said the agency wanted there to be a time out for all by having all
three children go for a weekend visit at Child 2’s and Child 3’s
birth father’s home. The Foster Care Supervisor reported she and
the Foster Care Worker were on a three-way call with the
Caregiver about the case matter. She began the conversation by
asking the Caregiver what happened. The Foster Care Supervisor
admitted that after the Caregiver was seeming to give a “vanilla”
explanation of the incident (meaning to sugar coat the incident),
she challenged the Caregiver over what the Caregiver was saying.
The Foster Care Supervisor said she is a loud talker; and she
admitted to talking loudly during the call. She reported loud talking
occurred both ways. The Caregiver was trying to talk over her.
3

The Foster Care Supervisor denied yelling at or berating the
Caregiver.
On 5/6/2024 I interviewed the Foster Care Worker about the
allegations by telephone. She affirmed being on the three-way call
with the Caregiver and the Foster Care Supervisor. The Foster
Care Worker said she called the Foster Care Supervisor, and then
added the Caregiver to the call. She affirmed the purpose of the
call with the Caregiver as that reported by the Foster Care
Supervisor. She reported the Foster Care Supervisor did the
majority of the talking during the three-way call. She said there
was back and forth conversation during the call with quick talking,
but no yelling or raised voices. She said there was a point when
the Foster Care Supervisor said she was disappointed with the
actions the Caregiver and the birth mother took, that it seemed
they put the birth mother’s feelings over Child 1’s, but no one
yelled or berated the Caregiver.
Document Review:
MISCAWIS Case record for Child 1, Child 2 and Child 3 which
showed:
• All three children are temporary court wards.
• All three children were placed in the Caregiver’s home on
8/9/2023.
Analysis The agency is in compliance with this rule because the Foster
Care Supervisor and Foster Care Worker who were on the call
with the Caregiver both denied the allegations; and there is no one
else to corroborate the allegations.
Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
4

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Continuation of the agency’s current licensing status is recommended.
